body:
Hello, I'm currently a GSOC aspirant, and I was curious if @gracewgao was still working on this.

If it is possible, I'd love to try working on this too.

>I was curious if @gracewgao was still working on this.

The protocol here would be to wait for a week or two and assume "no" if there's no reaction.

Hi, @mloning,  @fkiraly,
I'm new to contributing, and I was paying attention to this issue for some time. I have a few questions in order to clarify that I'm on the right track.

- According to the description of prediction intervals,
![sigma hat](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43887812/110738921-bfd04480-81f5-11eb-9077-076b8a5b8179.JPG)
(In this equation)
   1. T must be the length of the training dataset, right?
   2. Is the number of parameters estimated in the forecasting method(K) is 1 for this issue?

- Other than that, everything is clear according to the [document](https://otexts.com/fpp3/prediction-intervals.html).
- I looked at the [NaiveForecaster](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/sktime/forecasting/naive.py), and I want to know that, what is the best way to return the prediction intervals,
   1. From a separate function inside the [NaiveForecaster](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/sktime/forecasting/naive.py)?
   2. Or from the **predict** function under [_sktime.py](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/15c5ccba8999ddfc52fe37fe4d6a7ff39a19ece3/sktime/forecasting/base/_sktime.py#L206)?
   3. Is there any other forecasting method in Sktime that the prediction interval already exists to use as an example?
   4. Or is there any other approach that you would like to suggest?
Hey, sorry I never got the chance to work on this - someone else is definitely welcome to take this on!

@mloning, Thank you for the reply, 
I think I understand. I'll be implementing this, and I'll do a draft PR.

I would like to implement the prediction intervals for the NaiveForcaster. The approach I will be adopting is gotten from the FPP book. Since h is the number of steps ahead to predict. fh (the forecast horizon) = h. Each strategy (last, mean and drift) in the NaiveForcaster will be implemented accordingly.

issue.title: Naive forecaster pred intervals (Draft PR)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
 Prediction intervals for NaiveForecaster #480
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Implement for #480 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

1. New function under naive.py NaiveForecaster
2. Edit for _predict under _BaseWindowForecaster in _sktime.py (To return the results)
3. New unit testing for Naive forecaster pred intervals (Currently failing need to add expected prediction intervals to fix)

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

- [ ] _predict_intervals in naive.py 
- [ ] _predict in _BaseWindowForecaster

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->
Please suggest a package to calculate multiplier(C) in _predict_intervals or in a commit I'll do it with the equation or with another package.
#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [X] Added a unit test, currently failing, needs the expected predict intervals for the function.
##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
Please take a look at the Draft PR. I have some questions that are mentioned in the code (As comments).
And please let me know.
